sections.title: Introduction to Robotics & Electronics
sections.description: Hey newbie! Robotics and electronics are all about making cool stuff happen with circuits and code. Electronics powers things like your phone, while robotics brings machines to life—like a Roomba vacuuming your floor. Let’s start with the basics!

content.subtitle: Key Concepts
content.text: Electricity is the juice that flows through wires—like water in pipes. Voltage (V) pushes it, current (I) is how much flows, and resistance (R) slows it down. Ohm’s Law (V = I × R) ties it all together. Circuits are the paths electricity follows, and components like resistors and LEDs make them fun!

content.subtitle: Tools You’ll Need
content.text: Grab a multimeter to check your circuits (like a tech doctor), a breadboard for mess-free testing, jumper wires to connect stuff, and a battery or USB for power.

projects.title: Light a Bulb
projects.description: Hook up an LED, battery, and wires on a breadboard. Flip the switch and bam—light! It’s your first step into electronics.

projects.title: Paper Circuit Card
projects.description: Use copper tape, a coin battery, and an LED to make a glowing card. Perfect for impressing your friends with techy crafts!

sections.realLifeExample: Your phone charger uses circuits to tame electricity—same ideas you’re playing with here.

sections.title: Microcontrollers: The Brains Behind the Action
sections.description: Microcontrollers are the tiny brains that run your robot—like the CPU in your game console. They take inputs (like a button press) and control outputs (like lights). Let’s meet them!

content.subtitle: Popular Picks
content.text: Arduino Uno is your beginner buddy—easy and cheap. Raspberry Pi 4 is a mini-computer for big projects. ESP32 adds Wi-Fi magic, and Micro:bit is super simple for quick wins.

content.subtitle: Key Specs
content.text: Digital pins handle on/off stuff (like LEDs), analog pins read sensors, memory stores your code, and clock speed is how fast it thinks.

tutorials.title: Arduino vs. Raspberry Pi vs. ESP32

projects.title: Blink an LED
projects.description: Connect an LED to an Arduino and make it flash with code. It’s the ‘Hello World’ of robotics!

projects.title: Button Toggle
projects.description: Press a button to flip an LED on or off. Your first taste of controlling things!

sections.realLifeExample: Your thermostat uses a microcontroller to keep your room cozy.

sections.title: Arduino: Your Beginner-Friendly Playground
sections.description: Arduino is the MVP for newbies—simple, cheap (like $20), and perfect for starting out. Let’s set it up and make some magic happen!

content.subtitle: Getting Started
content.text: You’ll need an Arduino Uno, USB cable, breadboard, LEDs, 220Ω resistors, buttons, and wires. Download the Arduino IDE, plug in, and pick your board.

content.subtitle: Programming Basics
content.text: Code runs in two parts: setup() for one-time stuff and loop() for repeating action. Use digitalWrite() to turn stuff on, analogRead() for sensors, and if-else to decide things.

projects.title: Traffic Light
projects.description: Use red, yellow, and green LEDs to mimic a traffic signal with delays. Feel like a city planner!

projects.title: Room Alarm
projects.description: Add a buzzer and PIR sensor to beep when someone sneaks in—snack security activated!

projects.title: Dimmer Switch
projects.description: Twist a potentiometer to fade an LED. It’s like a mini DJ light show!

sections.realLifeExample: Automatic doors use sensors and microcontrollers to open when you walk up.

sections.title: Sensors: Giving Your Robot Senses
sections.description: Sensors are your robot’s eyes and ears—detecting light, heat, or motion. Let’s hook them up and see what they can do!

content.subtitle: Common Sensors
content.text: TMP36 checks temperature, LDR senses light, HC-SR04 measures distance with sound, PIR spots motion, and touch sensors feel contact.

content.subtitle: Using Them
content.text: Connect to Arduino pins, read data with code, and trigger stuff—like buzzing if it’s too hot.

projects.title: Smart Thermometer
projects.description: Show temp on an LCD screen with a TMP36 sensor—like your own weather gadget!

projects.title: Darkness Detector
projects.description: Turn on an LED when it’s dark with an LDR. Nightlight vibes!

projects.title: Obstacle Avoider
projects.description: Make a bot stop or turn with an ultrasonic sensor—like a tiny self-driving car!

sections.realLifeExample: Your car’s backup beeper uses ultrasonics to warn you.

sections.title: Actuators: Making Things Move
sections.description: Actuators are your robot’s muscles—turning signals into motion or sound. Let’s get rolling!

content.subtitle: Types of Actuators
content.text: DC motors spin wheels, servos move to exact angles, steppers step precisely, buzzers beep, and solenoids push or pull.

content.subtitle: Controlling Them
content.text: Use PWM for speed, libraries like Servo.h for ease, and extra power for big stuff—Arduino’s 5V won’t cut it alone.

projects.title: Rolling Bot
projects.description: Add DC motors and wheels to a chassis and drive it around—like a toy car you built!

projects.title: Sweeping Arm
projects.description: Use a servo to sweep side-to-side—like a mini wiper for your robot.

projects.title: Doorbell
projects.description: Program a buzzer to play a tune when a button’s pressed. Ding-dong!

sections.realLifeExample: Electric car windows roll with DC motors.

sections.title: Powering Your Projects
sections.description: No power, no fun! Let’s figure out how to keep your creations alive and kicking.

content.subtitle: Power Options
content.text: Use AA batteries, a 9V, LiPos for rechargeables, or a wall adapter for steady juice.

content.subtitle: Safety Tips
content.text: Match + and -, use regulators (like 7805) to avoid frying stuff, and unplug when tinkering.

projects.title: Battery-Powered Lamp
projects.description: Run an LED off AA batteries with a switch—like a portable nightlight!

sections.realLifeExample: Your smoke detector sips power from a 9V battery.

sections.title: Raspberry Pi: Stepping Up Your Game
sections.description: Ready for more? Raspberry Pi is a tiny computer for bigger projects—like a mini laptop for robotics!

content.subtitle: Getting Started
content.text: Grab a Pi 4, microSD card, power supply, and HDMI setup. Flash Raspberry Pi OS and boot it up.

content.subtitle: Why It Rocks
content.text: It’s got power for video, Wi-Fi, and coding in Python—way easier than Arduino’s C++.

projects.title: Weather Station
projects.description: Use a DHT11 sensor to show temp and humidity—like your own weather app!

projects.title: Pi-Powered Car
projects.description: Add motors and control a bot with your keyboard.

projects.title: Smart Light
projects.description: Toggle an LED over Wi-Fi with a simple web app.

sections.realLifeExample: Smart TVs use Pi-like tech to stream your shows.

sections.title: Advanced Topics: Going Beyond the Basics
sections.description: Feeling pro yet? Let’s push it further with soldering, wireless, and even some robot smarts!

content.subtitle: Soldering
content.text: Join stuff permanently with a soldering iron—makes your projects sturdy.

content.subtitle: Wireless
content.text: Bluetooth (HC-05) or Wi-Fi (ESP32) lets you control stuff from your phone.

content.subtitle: Computer Vision
content.text: Add a camera and spot things with OpenCV—like a robot detective!

projects.title: Soldered LED Board
projects.description: Solder LEDs onto a board for a custom light show.

projects.title: Bluetooth RC Car
projects.description: Drive a bot with your phone—remote control vibes!

projects.title: Face-Tracking Bot
projects.description: Use a Pi Camera to follow faces—like a selfie robot!

sections.realLifeExample: Self-driving cars use vision and wireless tech to cruise around.

Explore Sensors: Add senses like temp or motion.
Add Motion: Control motors for moving bots.
Power Up: Keep your projects juiced safely.
